issues.text: whether the memorandum of appeal presented to the High Court court-fee was payable under section 7(iv)(e) or article 17 of Schedule II of the Court-Fees Act

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave granted by the Privy Council and limited to the question of court-fee, viz., whether the memorandum of appeal presented to the High Court court-fee was payable under section 7  iv   e  or article 17 of Schedule II of the Court

issues.text: The question for determination in this appeal is whether the order of the Judicial Commissioner demanding additional court-fee can be sustained in law

anchor.surface_text: The question for determination in this appeal is whether the order of the Judicial Commissioner demanding additional court-fee can be sustained in law. A memorandum of appeal, as provided in article 1 of Schedule I of the Court-Fees Act, has to be stamped

issues.text: whether the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped arose in the following circumstances Edward-Mills Co. Ltd. is a joint stock company situate in Beawar, Ajmer- Merwara.

issues.text: whether the relief claimed in the memorandum of appeal was purely declaratory or included consequential relief

anchor.surface_text: The only relief claimed in the memorandum of appeal was the first one mentioned in the plaint. This relief being purely of a declaratory character, the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped under article 17 of Schedule II It is always open to the appellant

issues.text: whether it was open to the Judicial Commissioner to canvass the question whether the suit with the second prayer eliminated from it fell within the mischief of the proviso to section 42 of the Specific Relief Act for purposes of court-fee

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of deciding whether the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped according to the subjectmatter of the appeal, it was not open to the Judicial Commissioner to canvass the question whether the suit with the second prayer eliminated from it fell within the mischief of the proviso to section 42 of the Specific Relief Act.

issues.text: in view of the provisions of section 12 of the Court-Fees Act ... the decision of the Judicial Commissioner was final, and could not be challenged in appeal

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended that in view of the provisions of section 12 of the Court-Fees Act it should be held that the decision of the Judicial Commissioner was final, and could not be challenged in appeal. Section 12 of the Court-Fees Act enacts as follows

issues.text: whether the finality under section 12 of the Court-Fees Act extends to questions of category under which a suit or appeal falls or only to valuation pure and simple

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 of the Court-Fees Act enacts as follows Every question relating to valuation for the purpose of determining the amount of any fee chargeable under this chapter ... The provisions of this section have to be read and construed keeping in view the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.answer: only to valuation pure and simple / appraisement, not category

issues.text: the construction of section 12 reconciling the provisions of the Court-Fees Act with that of the Code of Civil Procedure
whether the Judicial Commissioner decided a question relating to valuation for the purpose of determining the amount of any fee chargeable under section 12

arguments.claim: Memorandum of appeal stamped according to value of relief claimed therein per article 1 Schedule I Court-Fees Act

anchor.surface_text: memorandum of appeal, as provided in article 1 of Schedule I of the Court-Fees Act, has to be stamped according to the value of the subject-matter in dispute in appeal in other words, the relief claimed in the memorandum of appeal determines the value of the appeal for purposes of court-fee.

arguments.claim: Only purely declaratory relief claimed in memorandum so properly stamped under article 17 Schedule II Court-Fees Act

anchor.surface_text: The only relief claimed in the memorandum of appeal was the first one mentioned in the plaint. This relief being purely of a declaratory character, the memorandum of appeal was properly stamped under article 17 of Schedule II

arguments.claim: Appellant can relinquish part of claim in appeal and limit to declaratory relief without additional fee

anchor.surface_text: It is always open to the appellant in appeal to give up a portion of his claim and to restrict it. holdings.text: No claim for a consequential relief can be read within this prayer. The words that defendant 2 has no right to act as chairman are mere repetition and reiteration of what is contained in the opening sentence of the paragraph. This contention of Mr. Setalvad, therefore, cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: therefore the Judicial Commissioner was right in demanding additional court-fee the value of the consequential relief. It was said that the words that respondent No. 2 had no right to act as chairman and managing director amounted to a claim for consequential relief. We are unable to agree. The claim contained in the first relief of the plaint is to the effect that it be declared that defendant No. 2 has no right to act as chairman an managing director because of his appointment being illegal, invalid, and ultra vires. The declaration claimed is in negative form that defendant No. 2 has no

holdings.reasoning_summary: First prayer is negative declaration of no right; no express or implied consequential relief claimed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consensus of High Courts limits s12 to valuation/appraisement not category; textual diff s5/s12; category question of law antecedent; reconciles with CPC appealability

holdings.text: in the present case the Judicial Commissioner decided none of these questions and his decision cannot be said to be one falling within the ambit of section 12.
